title: Outbreak & Epidemiology Quiz
description: Comprehensive quiz covering outbreak investigation, epidemiologic analysis, MDRO management, and infection control in outbreak settings

questions.question: An outbreak is defined as:
options: Any infection in a healthcare facility
Two or more cases of the same infection
An increase in cases above the expected baseline
A single case of a rare disease
questions.explanation: An outbreak is an increase in the number of cases above what is normally expected in a defined population and time period. The baseline must be established through surveillance.

questions.question: The chain of infection consists of:
questions.explanation: The chain of infection has 6 links: pathogen, reservoir, portal of exit, mode of transmission, portal of entry, and susceptible host. Breaking any link can prevent infection transmission.

questions.question: Standard precautions in outbreak settings should be applied to:
options: All patients in all healthcare settings
questions.explanation: Standard precautions are the foundation of infection prevention and must be applied to all patients in all healthcare settings, regardless of outbreak status.

questions.question: The index case is:
options: The first case identified in an outbreak
The case that introduced the pathogen
The last case in an outbreak
questions.explanation: The index case is the first case identified in an outbreak investigation. It may or may not be the primary case (the case that introduced the pathogen into the population).

questions.question: Contact tracing is performed to:
options: Identify exposed individuals who may develop disease
questions.explanation: Contact tracing identifies individuals who had contact with confirmed cases to monitor for symptoms, provide prophylaxis if indicated, and prevent further transmission.

questions.question: The difference between isolation and quarantine is:
options: Isolation is for confirmed cases, quarantine is for exposed individuals
Quarantine is for confirmed cases, isolation is for exposed individuals
Isolation is voluntary, quarantine is mandatory
questions.explanation: Isolation separates sick people with a contagious disease from those who are not sick. Quarantine separates and restricts movement of people who were exposed but are not yet sick.

questions.question: Hand hygiene during an outbreak should be performed:
options: Only when hands are visibly soiled
questions.explanation: Hand hygiene should be performed before and after patient contact following WHO 5 Moments, regardless of outbreak status. It is the single most important measure to prevent transmission.

questions.question: A case definition includes:
questions.explanation: A case definition includes clinical criteria (signs/symptoms), laboratory criteria (test results), and epidemiologic criteria (time, place, person) to standardize case identification.

questions.question: Incidence measures:
options: Total existing cases at a point in time
New cases occurring over a time period
questions.explanation: Incidence measures new cases occurring during a specific time period, while prevalence measures all existing cases at a point in time.

questions.question: Environmental cleaning during an outbreak should:
options: Focus on high-touch surfaces with appropriate disinfectants
questions.explanation: Environmental cleaning should focus on high-touch surfaces using EPA-registered disinfectants appropriate for the pathogen, with increased frequency during outbreaks.

questions.question: The first step in outbreak investigation is:
questions.explanation: Before launching a full investigation, you must verify that an outbreak truly exists by confirming diagnoses, checking for reporting artifacts, and comparing current rates to baseline.

questions.question: A point-source epidemic curve shows:
options: Sharp peak followed by gradual decline
questions.explanation: A point-source outbreak (single exposure) shows a sharp peak as cases develop after one incubation period, followed by gradual decline as the epidemic exhausts susceptible individuals.

questions.question: Attack rate is calculated as:
questions.explanation: Attack rate = (Number of cases / Population at risk) × 100. It measures the proportion of the at-risk population that develops disease during an outbreak.

questions.question: Secondary attack rate measures:
options: Cases among contacts of primary cases
questions.explanation: Secondary attack rate measures the proportion of susceptible contacts of primary cases who develop disease within one incubation period, indicating person-to-person transmission efficiency.

questions.question: A line list should include:
options: Demographic, clinical, and epidemiologic data for each case
questions.explanation: A line list is a table with one row per case, including demographic data (age, sex), clinical data (symptoms, outcomes), and epidemiologic data (exposure, onset date, location).

questions.question: Cohorting during an outbreak means:
options: Isolating each patient in a private room
Grouping patients with the same infection together
questions.explanation: Cohorting groups patients infected with the same organism together (and assigns dedicated staff) when private rooms are unavailable, preventing cross-transmission to uninfected patients.

questions.question: The incubation period is useful in outbreak investigation to:
questions.explanation: The incubation period (time from exposure to symptom onset) helps estimate when exposure occurred by working backward from illness onset dates, narrowing the investigation timeframe.

questions.question: A spot map in outbreak investigation shows:
questions.explanation: A spot map plots cases by geographic location (e.g., hospital floor plan, city map) to identify spatial clustering and potential environmental sources.

questions.question: Environmental sampling during an outbreak should be performed:
options: When an environmental source is suspected
questions.explanation: Environmental sampling should be targeted when epidemiologic evidence suggests an environmental source (e.g., water, equipment, surfaces) and can guide control measures.

questions.question: Case fatality rate is calculated as:
questions.explanation: Case fatality rate = (Deaths from disease / Cases of disease) × 100. It measures the severity of disease by showing the proportion of cases that result in death.

questions.question: A relative risk (RR) of 3.5 with 95% CI [2.1-5.8] means:
options: The association is not statistically significant
Exposed individuals are 3.5 times more likely to develop disease
35% of cases are due to the exposure
questions.explanation: RR = 3.5 means exposed individuals have 3.5 times the risk of disease compared to unexposed. The 95% CI excludes 1.0, indicating the association is statistically significant.

questions.question: An odds ratio (OR) of 0.4 with 95% CI [0.2-0.8] suggests:
options: The exposure is protective against disease
No association between exposure and disease
questions.explanation: OR < 1.0 indicates the exposure is protective (reduces disease risk). The 95% CI excludes 1.0, confirming statistical significance. OR = 0.4 means 60% risk reduction.

questions.question: A p-value of 0.03 means:
options: 3% of cases are due to chance
There is a 3% probability the observed association is due to chance
questions.explanation: A p-value of 0.03 means there is a 3% probability that the observed association occurred by chance alone. Since p < 0.05, the result is statistically significant.

questions.question: Sensitivity of a diagnostic test measures:
options: Proportion of true positives correctly identified
Proportion of true negatives correctly identified
Proportion of positive tests that are true positives
Proportion of negative tests that are true negatives
questions.explanation: Sensitivity = True Positives / (True Positives + False Negatives). A highly sensitive test correctly identifies most people with the disease (few false negatives).

questions.question: Specificity of a diagnostic test measures:
options: Proportion of true positives correctly identified
Proportion of true negatives correctly identified
Proportion of positive tests that are true positives
Proportion of negative tests that are true negatives
questions.explanation: Specificity = True Negatives / (True Negatives + False Positives). A highly specific test correctly identifies most people without the disease (few false positives).

questions.question: Positive predictive value (PPV) is:
options: Probability that a person with disease tests positive
Probability that a person without disease tests negative
Probability that a positive test indicates true disease
Probability that a negative test indicates no disease
questions.explanation: PPV = True Positives / (True Positives + False Positives). It answers: 'If the test is positive, what is the probability the person truly has the disease?' PPV depends on disease prevalence.

questions.question: A propagated epidemic curve shows:
options: Multiple peaks with progressively increasing intervals
questions.explanation: A propagated (person-to-person) outbreak shows multiple peaks separated by approximately one incubation period, as each generation of cases infects the next generation.

questions.question: Colonization pressure in an ICU is calculated as:
questions.explanation: Colonization pressure = (Colonized patient-days / Total patient-days) × 100. It measures the proportion of time patients are exposed to colonized patients, predicting transmission risk.

questions.question: In a case-control study during an outbreak, you should:
options: Compare cases vs controls for exposure history
questions.explanation: Case-control studies compare cases (people with disease) to controls (people without disease) to determine if exposure rates differ, helping identify risk factors retrospectively.

questions.question: Transmission-based precautions for MRSA outbreak include:
questions.explanation: MRSA requires contact precautions (gloves and gown) in addition to standard precautions, as transmission occurs through direct contact or contact with contaminated surfaces.

questions.question: During a CRE outbreak, active surveillance cultures should target:
options: High-risk patients and contacts of cases
questions.explanation: Active surveillance for CRE should target high-risk patients (ICU, transplant, ventilated) and contacts of known cases to identify colonized patients early and prevent transmission.

questions.question: Whole genome sequencing (WGS) shows 2 isolates differ by 5 SNPs. This suggests:
options: The isolates are likely from the same transmission chain
questions.explanation: Isolates differing by <10-20 SNPs are typically considered part of the same transmission chain, as bacteria accumulate mutations during person-to-person spread. WGS provides high-resolution outbreak tracking.

questions.question: A waterborne outbreak investigation should include:
options: Water testing, distribution system review, and case-control study
questions.explanation: Waterborne outbreak investigation requires water microbiologic testing, water distribution system review (pressure, cross-connections), epidemiologic studies, and clinical case finding.

questions.question: Healthcare-associated outbreaks differ from community outbreaks in that they:
options: Involve vulnerable populations with multiple comorbidities
questions.explanation: Healthcare-associated outbreaks involve vulnerable populations (immunocompromised, elderly, critically ill) with higher risk of severe outcomes, requiring aggressive infection control and often involving MDROs.

questions.question: An outbreak should be declared over when:
options: Two incubation periods pass with no new cases
questions.explanation: An outbreak is declared over after two maximum incubation periods pass without new cases, ensuring sufficient time for any incubating infections to manifest.

questions.question: Post-outbreak surveillance should continue for:
options: At least 2-3 incubation periods after outbreak ends
questions.explanation: Post-outbreak surveillance should continue for at least 2-3 incubation periods after the outbreak ends to detect any late cases or recurrence, ensuring true outbreak termination.

questions.question: Root cause analysis after an outbreak should identify:
questions.explanation: Root cause analysis identifies system failures, process breakdowns, and contributing factors (not individual blame) to implement sustainable improvements and prevent recurrence.

questions.question: During a C. difficile outbreak, environmental cleaning should use:
questions.explanation: C. difficile spores are resistant to alcohol and many disinfectants. EPA-registered sporicidal disinfectants (e.g., bleach at 1:10 dilution) are required for environmental cleaning.

questions.question: Foodborne outbreak investigation requires:
options: Food history, leftover food testing, and case-control study
questions.explanation: Foodborne outbreak investigation requires detailed food histories, leftover food microbiologic testing, kitchen inspection, case-control studies to identify implicated food items, and traceback.

questions.question: Legal reporting of outbreaks to public health authorities is:
options: Required for notifiable diseases and unusual events
questions.explanation: Healthcare facilities must report outbreaks of notifiable diseases, unusual events, and potential public health threats to local/state health departments per legal requirements and CDC guidelines.

questions.question: You identify 8 cases of Burkholderia cepacia in ICU patients over 2 weeks. All isolates are genetically identical. Blood cultures were drawn using a new brand of antiseptic. What is the MOST likely explanation?
questions.explanation: Burkholderia can survive in antiseptics and disinfectants. Sudden cluster + new product + identical isolates + no clinical illness suggests pseudo-outbreak from contaminated antiseptic rather than true patient-to-patient transmission.

questions.question: During an outbreak in a neonatal ICU with extremely premature infants, the MOST ethical approach to cohorting is:
options: Cohort all infants regardless of infection status
Cohort infected infants together with dedicated staff
Refuse cohorting due to ethical concerns
questions.explanation: Cohorting infected infants with dedicated staff protects uninfected vulnerable infants while providing appropriate care to infected infants. This balances individual patient needs with population protection.

questions.question: A novel respiratory pathogen causes an outbreak with 30% mortality. Media requests information. Your BEST response is:
options: Provide transparent, accurate information through designated spokesperson
questions.explanation: Transparent, accurate, timely communication through a designated trained spokesperson builds trust, prevents misinformation, and guides public protective actions while respecting patient privacy.

questions.question: Outbreak modeling predicts 50 additional cases in 2 weeks without intervention. Resources are limited. Priority should be given to:
options: Implementing control measures to prevent new cases
questions.explanation: Prevention of new cases through control measures (isolation, cohorting, enhanced cleaning, staff education) is more effective and resource-efficient than treating preventable cases.

questions.question: An outbreak investigation reveals a healthcare worker as the likely source. The MOST appropriate action is:
options: Conduct confidential investigation, provide treatment/education, and reassign if needed
Ignore findings to protect the worker
questions.explanation: Healthcare workers deserve confidential investigation, appropriate medical care, education, and work restrictions if needed. Focus on system improvements, not blame. Protect patient safety while respecting worker rights.

questions.question: International Health Regulations (IHR) require reporting of outbreaks that may constitute:
options: Public health emergencies of international concern
questions.explanation: IHR (2005) requires countries to report events that may constitute a Public Health Emergency of International Concern (PHEIC) to WHO, including unusual/unexpected events with international spread potential.

questions.question: After-action review following an outbreak should focus on:
options: Documenting lessons learned and system improvements
questions.explanation: After-action review should be a blameless, structured process documenting what worked, what didn't, lessons learned, and actionable system improvements to enhance future outbreak preparedness and response.

questions.question: A new pathogen emerges with unknown transmission mode. Initial infection control should include:
options: Contact and droplet precautions plus airborne if aerosol-generating procedures
questions.explanation: For emerging pathogens with unknown transmission, use a precautionary approach with contact + droplet precautions, plus airborne precautions for aerosol-generating procedures, until transmission mode is clarified.

questions.question: Outbreak investigation reveals systemic failures in multiple departments. The BEST approach to policy development is:
options: Develop policies for each department separately
Create multidisciplinary team to develop integrated policies with leadership support
Wait for another outbreak to confirm findings
questions.explanation: Systemic failures require multidisciplinary collaboration (IPC, clinical, environmental services, administration) to develop integrated, evidence-based policies with leadership support and accountability.

questions.question: During an outbreak, you must balance individual patient rights with population protection. The ethical principle that BEST guides this decision is:
options: Beneficence and non-maleficence balanced with justice
questions.explanation: Outbreak response requires balancing beneficence (doing good), non-maleficence (avoiding harm) for individuals and populations, with justice (fair resource allocation). Ethical frameworks guide proportionate, necessary restrictions.
